titleInfo.title: Louisiana Cooperative Extension Oral History Project
titleInfo.subTitle: Gina E. Eubanks oral history interview, 2014

name.description: Gina E. Eubanks was born on June 11, 1956. She is a native of Clinton, East Feliciana Parish, Louisiana. She is the daughter of L.E. Eubanks and Ora (Davis) Eubanks. She participated in 4-H during high school. She attended Southern University and received a B.S. degree in clothing and textiles in 1977. Following her B.S. degree, she attended Oklahoma State University and earned a master?s degree in clothing and textiles in 1978. She also received a PhD in home economics from Oklahoma State University in 1987. In 1990, she joined Southern University as the coordinator of family and consumer sciences. She was named vice chancellor for extension in 2002. In May of 2013, she was named program leader of food and nutrition for the Louisiana State University AgCenter.

subject.topic: Southern University and A & M College--Faculty.

mods.note: Louisiana State University Libraries Special Collections (http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special)
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright is retained by Louisiana State University in accordance with U.S. copyright laws.

"E-mail lsudiglib@lsu.edu with questions or comments. See instructions for ordering reprints of this audio here: http://www.lib.lsu.edu/special/services/duplication.html Mention the ""Item number"" or ""Item URL"" in your request. "
mods.abstract: Eubanks discusses her early life in Clinton, East Feliciana Parish, Louisiana. She documents her time as a 4-H member during high school and how the extension agents genuinely cared for the club members. She also discusses how a job cleaning houses led her to earn her B.S. degree from Southern University. She discusses her time as a merchandiser for Goudchaux's department store and as an instructor at Alcorn State and Virginia Tech universities. Eventually she earned her Ph.D. from Oklahoma State University and joined the faculty at Southern University. She illustrates the difference between teaching in a college setting and an extension setting. Eubanks describes various aspects of extension, from purchasing her first sewing machine through extension to the new ability of agents to deliver presentations to community members via YouTube.
